creditline: Gift of Sam and Patty McCullough in celebration of the 100th anniversary of the Minneapolis Institute of Arts
description: backrest has vase-like central element with heart cutout at center; two scalloped elements at top corners of backrest; three rounded lobes at top of backrest; straight back legs with square cross-sections; front legs are turned with pad-like feet; turned spindles--spindle at front has three large knobs at center, top spindles on sides have even beadlike patterning; woven plant fiber seat in trapezoidal shape
text:
This chair’s maker chose some unusual elements for distinction. The vase-shaped splat, or center back section has a delightful cut-out heart. The undulating top rail features a “pagoda” design at the center and carved “ears” on each side. The flat-bottomed, carved pad feet and the curving back rail are the details of an ambitious craftsman.
 
The chair is distinctive, but so was its original owner. David Ellsworth (1709-1782) a selectman, commanded a New England company on behalf of Britain at the 1745 Siege of Louisbourg on the French-held Cape Breton Island in Nova Scotia. This was a decisive British victory in what was known in the North American colonies as “King George’s War,” part of the War of the Austrian Secession, which raged nearly worldwide from 1740-48.
title: East Windsor side chair
